awd_titl_txt: Eyes on the future: optimizing science output for next generation surveys with joint crowdsourced and automated classification techniques
awd_abstract_narration:
The successful use of citizen science to carry out "crowd-sourced" galaxy classifications from imaging data has shown clearly the availability of a vast resource of volunteer labor.  Future surveys will also produce spectra, breaking down light into its wavelengths to reveal the physical state of the galaxies.  The present, ambitious, project will extend the involvement of volunteers into these spectroscopic data, providing a richer experience for participants and addressing research in galaxy formation impossible to accomplish any other way.  If the scalability problem of handling massive amounts of spectral data can also be solved this way, the impact for the community and for the scientifically literate public will be enormous.

While crowdsourced galaxy classifications have proven their worth with a decade of images from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), several next generation surveys will be spectroscopic, which substantially increases the complexity of the data sets, while providing a much larger space for discovery.  Although having spectra for tens of millions of objects will allow a wide range of science, new tools are needed to maximize the scientific return.  Automatic algorithms alone will either struggle in identifying difficult features or produce highly contaminated samples to try to maximize completeness.  The volume of data from forthcoming surveys renders human scrutiny impractical.  This project will meet these challenges, extending to spectroscopic data the successful crowdsourcing approach used for imaging by the suite of Galaxy Zoo projects, and expanding previous NSF-supported work by this team.  There will be two components: (1) Galaxy Nurseries will build an emission line catalog through crowdsourced classifications of spectroscopic data; and (2) Clump Scout will identify clumpy galaxies in the SDSS.  Investigations with these catalogs will constrain galaxy formation models by (1) quantifying the fraction of galaxies with giant star-forming regions; (2) characterizing the internal variation of physical properties of such regions; and (3) comparing the gas metallicity of galaxies with and without these regions.

As with the previous image work, the high-level catalogs to be produced, and the new classification algorithms to be used, are to be released publicly, and will be a valuable resource for the community.  The study also continues the work to implement Galaxy Zoo in undergraduate astronomy courses, involving both graduate and undergraduate students.

Eyes on the Future - outcomes report

 

The field of galaxy evolution faces several new challenges. First, galaxies in the early universe (within a few billion years of the Big Bang) had much more chaotic structures than modern galaxies, and many appear dominated by bright, off-center ?clumps?. These clumps are forming new stars extremely quickly, and a significant fraction of the stars in existence today may have formed within them. Unfortunately, it has been difficult to form a clear picture of clumps? behavior because of their distance: To observe clumps as they existed billions of years ago, we must examine them from billions of lightyears away. These issues are compounded by the fact that astronomy is entering an era of ?big data?. While it was once possible for astronomers to manually examine every galaxy imaged by telescopes, upcoming projects will produce far more data than any scientist can examine by hand. Astronomers will need to automate the process of classifying galaxies, and these efforts must include methods for automatically detecting and measuring clumps.

 

During the lifetime of our grant, our group developed or refined methods of finding clumps that are scalable to the ?big data? era. These methods relied on the input of thousands of citizen scientists, or groups of thousands of volunteers who examined galaxies ?by eye?, which helped train or refine methods for fully automated detection. We then applied these methods to nearby, modern-universe galaxies imaged by the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), rather than distant and early universe galaxies. We chose to focus on the local universe because, although massive star-forming clumps are far less common nearby, local clumps can be examined in much more detail than their more distant counterparts. 

 

A key output of our work was the identification of more than 10,000 clumps in nearby galaxies through the citizen science project Galaxy Zoo: Clump Scout. Through this project, we recruited over 14,000 volunteers to examine images of SDSS galaxies on the Zooniverse web platform, and to mark any bright, star-forming regions they saw. We then pioneered a new method of combining the volunteers? marks, which took into account the ?complexity? of each image as well as the marking habits of each individual volunteer (Dickinson et al. 2022, in prep.). The clumps we identified represent the consensus of these 14,000+ volunteers, and constitute the largest catalog of nearby clumps ever identified. In addition to this, we identified over 500 clumps in a region of SDSS with higher imaging quality (known as ?Stripe 82?), with help from volunteers from the Galaxy Zoo: Hubble project as well as an automated clump identification algorithm based on ?contrasts? within an image. Finally, these catalogs were used to train a ?clump identifier? using state-of-the-art machine learning techniques. These identification methods are extensible to much larger datasets, and will help move clump science into the big data era.

 

The clump samples we identified have already resulted in scientific findings. First, clumps in local galaxies are exceedingly rare (we found that only 2-3% of nearby star-forming galaxies host clumps), and surprisingly, this was true for galaxies of all sizes. To explain the rarity of clumps today, we suggest that most clumps form as a result of cold, pristine gas flowing into their host galaxies. It is already known that this gas flow slowed over billions of years, so this could explain why the formation of clumps has slowed alongside it (Adams et al. 2022). To further investigate this idea, we are examining the environments of nearby clumpy galaxies to determine whether they are in more isolated or more crowded regions of space (Adams et al. 2022, in prep). We also investigated the theory that clumps ?migrate? within their galaxies, slowly growing older as they move from their galaxies? outskirts towards their centers. Our measurements challenge this theory: In our sample, there was no evidence that clumps near galaxy centers were any older than clumps near the outskirts (Mehta et al. 2021). This work has shed light on the way that giant clumps form, die, and impact their host galaxies, and the catalogs we produced will continue to enable clump science as we observe and study them with more powerful tools.
